content:
Let MMM be the category of metric spaces and Lipschitz maps. Let PPP be the category whose objects are spaces XXX equipped with a function d:X×X→Rd:X\times X\to\mathbb{R}d:X×X→R (no axioms) and whose morphisms from (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) to (X′,d′)(X',d')(X′,d′) are ordered pairs (α,f:X→Y)(\alpha,f:X\to Y)(α,f:X→Y) where fff satisfies ∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y)\forall x,y\in X\ldotp d'(f(x),f(y))<\alpha d(x,y)∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y). I'd like to say that MMM embeds as a full subcategory of PPP, but that is not the case. So what is going on here?

I have thought about this a bit: considering the canonical functor F:M→PF:M\to PF:M→P sending (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) to (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) and fff to (α,f)(\alpha,f)(α,f), where α\alphaα is the smallest value such that fff is α\alphaα-Lipschitz, let M′M'M′ be the full subcategory of PPP spanned by the image of FFF. Then the crucial fact is that the functor F:M→M′F:M\to M'F:M→M′ has a "pseudo-retraction", i.e. a functor P:M′→MP:M'\to MP:M′→M such that P∘F≅idMP\circ F\cong {\sf id}_MP∘F≅idM​. Oddly, I can't find any literature on such "pseudo-retractions". Anyone know of anything?
A more trivial example of this same thing is the functor C→C×1→C×D→C×D+EC\to C\times 1\to C\times D\to C\times D+EC→C×1→C×D→C×D+E, for categories CCC, DDD, and EEE.

Joshua Meyers said:

Let MMM be the category of metric spaces and Lipschitz maps. Let PPP be the category whose objects are spaces XXX equipped with a function d:X×X→Rd:X\times X\to\mathbb{R}d:X×X→R (no axioms) and whose morphisms from (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) to (X′,d′)(X',d')(X′,d′) are ordered pairs (α,f:X→Y)(\alpha,f:X\to Y)(α,f:X→Y) where fff satisfies ∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y)\forall x,y\in X\ldotp d'(f(x),f(y))<\alpha d(x,y)∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y). I'd like to say that MMM embeds as a full subcategory of PPP, but that is not the case. So what is going on here?

I have thought about this a bit: considering the canonical functor F:M→PF:M\to PF:M→P sending (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) to (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) and fff to (α,f)(\alpha,f)(α,f), where α\alphaα is the smallest value such that fff is α\alphaα-Lipschitz, let M′M'M′ be the full subcategory of PPP spanned by the image of FFF. Then the crucial fact is that the functor F:M→M′F:M\to M'F:M→M′ has a "pseudo-retraction", i.e. a functor P:M′→MP:M'\to MP:M′→M such that P∘F≅idMP\circ F\cong {\sf id}_MP∘F≅idM​. Oddly, I can't find any literature on such "pseudo-retractions". Anyone know of anything?

One thing that's not clear to me is that that smallest α\alphaα exists.

Shouldn't it be ≤\leq≤ rather than <<< in the condition ∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y)\forall x,y \in X. d'(f(x), f(y)) < \alpha d(x,y)∀x,y∈X.d′(f(x),f(y))<αd(x,y) ? Otherwise multiplication by two −×2:[0;1]→[0;2]-\times 2 : [0;1] \to [0;2]−×2:[0;1]→[0;2] does not satisfy the condition for α=2\alpha = 2α=2.
And even when a smallest α\alphaα exists, there is no reason that it would be functorial: if f(x)=2x:{0,1}→{0,1,2}f(x) = 2x : \{0,1\} \to \{0,1,2\}f(x)=2x:{0,1}→{0,1,2} and g(y)=min⁡(2,2y):{0,1,2}→{0,2}g(y) = \min(2, 2y) : \{0,1,2\}\to \{0,2\}g(y)=min(2,2y):{0,1,2}→{0,2} then P(f)=(2,f),P(g)=(2,g)P(f) = (2, f), P(g) = (2, g)P(f)=(2,f),P(g)=(2,g) but P(g∘f)=(2,g∘f)≠(2∗2,g∘f)=P(g)∘P(f)P(g \circ f) = (2, g\circ f) \neq (2*2, g\circ f) = P(g) \circ P(f)P(g∘f)=(2,g∘f)=(2∗2,g∘f)=P(g)∘P(f) (assuming composition in MMM multiplies the coefficients)

good points people, yeah it should be ≤\leq≤ rather than <<<; then a smallest α\alphaα always exists and is given by sup⁡x≠yd′(f(x),f(y))d(x,y)\sup_{x\neq y}\frac{d'(f(x),f(y))}{d(x,y)}supx=y​d(x,y)d′(f(x),f(y))​. But yeah, "smallest α\alphaα" is not preserved under composition, which causes problems.
So then what is the relationship between PPP and MMM?

Oh wow I can't believe it I think it's a cofunctor, as in @David Spivak's poly book! The mapping F:M→PF:M\to PF:M→P goes forward on objects and then maps morphisms backwards P(FX,FX′)→M(X,X′)P(FX,FX')\to M(X,X')P(FX,FX′)→M(X,X′) by (α,f)↦f(\alpha,f)\mapsto f(α,f)↦f.
What's more it's a "full cofunctor", which I define as a cofunctor where the backwards morphism maps are surjective
full functors ⊇\supseteq⊇ fully faithful functors === fully faithful cofunctors ⊆\subseteq⊆ full cofunctors
The middle equality is because when M(X,X′)≅P(FX,FX′)M(X,X')\cong P(FX,FX')M(X,X′)≅P(FX,FX′), the isomorphism can be thought of in either direction.
Thus full cofunctors strictly generalize full embeddings

Whoops I'm wrong! To be a cofunctor it would have to send any morphism FX→YFX\to YFX→Y in PPP back to a morphism X→X′X\to X'X→X′ for some X′X'X′ such that FX′=YFX'=YFX′=Y. But this is impossible as FFF is not surjective on objects.
OK I now think it's a span: M←IM′→FPM\xleftarrow{I} M'\xrightarrow{F} PMI​M′F​P, where III is full and essentially surjective and FFF is full and faithful.
M′M'M′ here is the full subcategory of PPP spanned by metric spaces.
But this still isn't all the structure that's there...
